title: 522 - Malaria Mondays Miniseries Part II: Why Haven’t We Eradicated Malaria?
itunes:title: 522 - Malaria Mondays Miniseries Part II: Why Haven’t We Eradicated Malaria?
description: Malaria, a mosquito-borne infection, affects some 228 million people globally each year, killing over 400,000 of them—primarily children under the age of 5. In part two of a miniseries, Thomas Locke, host of the Johns Hopkins Malaria Research Institute podcast “Malaria Minute” looks back at 1955 when the WHO launched its “Global Malaria Eradication Programme” that was expected to end malaria worldwide in five years. What went wrong, and where are we now in terms of efforts to fight back against one of the world’s most entrenched diseases? You can learn more about groundbreaking malaria research at malaria.jhsph.edu.
